pros:
1. Knowledge sharing 
2. Good company culture 
3. Career growth
cons:
1. High workloads 
2. Sales as service rather than partnership 
3. Mandatory - In person work

pros:
Lots of things for you to do. If u can handle that much, u get good career growth. 

Compensation has improved a lot over the years
cons: Constant reorgs. So even if u r on a good team now doesnt mean u will have a good team 6 mo or 1 year later.

pros: Lots of opportunities to build and work cross functionally. Working at Amazon will give you unlocks you can take elsewhere- like mechanisms.
cons: Morale and culture can change on a dime. I found that leadership we’re not curious and instead lead with a do more with less and it’s not hard attitude.

pros: Innovative, fast, principled, results-oriented, smart people, no downtime, infinite scale, great compensation, etc.
cons: Cut throat, relentless pressure, unforgiving, high complexity, etc. there’s nothing like working at Amazon on the good and bad.

pros: Fair recognition in industry while might still be looked down upon compared with top players
cons: Worst rsu investment plan and politics driven to harm people who only focused on working
reasonResign: Harmed by the special micro management while contributing most in teams

summary: Poor Work Life Balance, New hires are paid 1.5x for an existing employee whose promoted to the same level
pros:
Tech stack is very updated
Global scale impact
Good learning opportunities
cons:
Poor work life balance
Micro management culture
YoY increments are horrible (1-2%)
No office amenities

summary: Career growth takes a hit due to poor management
pros:
Good compensation and benefits.
Good name to have on your resume.
cons: Work culture is bad. There is no transparency and no accountability for management failure. It could affect career growth badly.

summary: At its peak, an unique and exhilerating culture, but now increasingly bureaucratic and dysfunctional
pros: At its best, Amazon is a unique and deeply rewarding place to work. Small ("two-pizza") teams with complete autonomy to make decisions and move quickly, incredibly smart team-mates with a high sense of ownership over everything they do, and a culture that encourages truth-seeking over social cohesion make for a great place to work, if these are the things that motivate you. A culture of writing (and reading) detailed narrative-form documents encourages critical thinking and high-quality decision-making. When Amazon works well, it is like a vast federation of startups, backed by the financial might and infrastructure of a trillion-dollar tech behemoth.
cons: Unfortunately, the Amazon described above has been in serious decline for years now. Too many executives in recent years hired at Director and VP level from outside, with no understanding at all of what Amazon culture truly looks like, who make things like the Amazon Leadership Principles (which used to be a remarkable framework that determined how every decision in the company was made) into meaningless buzzwords, like those things are at most other companies.

pros:
Good compensation and good gains on RSU. 
Probably a good place for freshers but not for experienced guys.
cons: Its all about the priorities. If you are happy to work 15 hours a day and if that makes you happy, probably Amazon is a good place for you, but for people who want to enjoy life with family and friends then Amazon will take away your peace and happiness.

summary: Big company, lots of variability depending on team and org
pros: Has decent compensation compared to the tech industry in general.
cons: It's probably the MAANG out there in pretty much every category.

pros: Focus on getting things done and making customers happy. Engineering bar is quite high and you learn a lot.
cons:
Operations is non trivial effort and depending on the org, you might have more ops
 work.

summary: Good work life balance for my team. At times, does get hectic but manageable
pros: Career growth is really good. Got to learn a lot.
cons: Kind of a rat race at times and heavy competition in order to not be the lowest performer on the team.

pros:
Structure and Mechanisms work. 
Good Feedback process. 
Nice offices (so i like RTO)
cons: Some (asian unfortunately) managers need to understand that this is the US and we expect WLB.

pros: Good if you are joining with a good salary (e.g., MBA programme).
cons:
If your salary is low, it is almost impossible to get it higher even if you are top performer.
Culture differs greatly from org to org.
Lost its startup spirit, hard to get things done without being stuck to politics and migrations.

pros:
Compensation (generally) 
Learning from other smart people
Coworkers create community
cons:
There are so many politics 
Culture has taken a downturn since leadership changed- monitor and comply vs innovation 
Bureaucracy monitoring creates more bureaucracy

summary: Great to learn to work at scale but terrible culture kill motivation
pros:
Work on interesting project at a massive scale
Coworkers are smart
cons:
Cutthroat culture is not for everyone
Career growth is very political and slow

pros: Still a good company, if you are in the right team, and report to the right manager. Big enough to find decent like-minded colleagues.
cons: Bad hire at the senior management poisoned the culture in some organisations making them far from being “Amazonian”

summary: Team dependent but overall bad WLB and good comp
pros: Compensation, impact, tech stack. Can learn a lot and tech is always up to industry standards.
cons: Hectic at times. When deadlines come in expect to work long hours. Bad benefits

pros: Great for past paced learning and experience which is nice!
cons: it gets heavy and tight deadlines makes you feel drowned

pros: Title + comp is great. You'll gain a lot of marketable skills.
cons: Deadlines are pretty rough sometimes. Huge company and its easy to feel lost sometimes.

summary: Can be fine if you land on a good team
pros: Lots of not so good stories about working at Amazon, if you land on a good team and have a solid 4 year starting comp it can be a fine place to work.
cons: Lots of bad vibes, expectations can be very high, the work backwards model usually results in bad effort estimates by leadership and unnecessary. The company is too mature and big for any reasonable expectations of fast and quick rises to the top.

pros: Amazon is best place for folks who are career driven
cons: The moment you stop proving yourself you will be out of company in next olr

summary: Good Leadership principles are being diluted by incompetent middle management
pros: Good start up place to learn and grow your career
cons: Too many incompetent middle management who only cares about growing their own turf at the expense of subordinates.

pros: Some great colleagues who will go the distance with you!
cons: Many short sighted senior leaders and brown nosing toxic managers

summary: Get paid for what is expected of you
pros: Good tech work, fast paced, good growth and competitive pay.
cons: Work life balance takes a bit depending on which team/org you are part of.

pros:
Great learning and great pay.
Compensation is very high
Operations
cons: No wlb late night work.. keep running always to survive pip

pros:
Just don’t be here. I would rather choose any small local organisation anytime with lower pay.
It’s all about metrics in operations
cons: Sometimes team members are good. Now that depends on with team you are.

pros: If you find the right team, you can have a good wlb and progress.  Lots of learning material as well, if you make time for it.
cons: Compensation philosophy isn't employee focused.  If you have one off year (not TT) you set yourself back years unless you get promoted.

summary: Intense culture, can learn a lot
pros: Can learn a lot, internal mobility is good, brand name
cons: Frugality, work life balance. It’s an intense culture. Things are chaotic and disorganized.

summary: Great place to learn and develop as a software engineer, have worked in various teams internally.
pros:
1. Lot of learning opportunities.
2. Get to work as a whole package , Software engineer , qa , product , sre etc.
3. Some teams are really good with amazing managers who genuinely want you to grow in career.
cons:
1. Lot of teams are toxic and credit stealing teammates to save their jobs and show others down.
2. Most of teams have constant firing fear created and no backing team support and do not work as a team and work as a credit stealers.
3. Couple of Managers are not competent enough to understand tech and have few favourites in the team who influence their decision making.
4. Not so great benefits.
